title: Part 2
content:
Part 2

DAY 1, DAY 2. Each class tried its best to avoid combat and focused solely on securing supplies.

They held one another in check and watched, scurrying about various places to gather supplies.

The only spectacular development, to repeat myself, was the surprise attack by Class B and the few-minute shootout on the second day that we initiated to secure supplies.

However, moment by moment, the off-limits areas were steadily increasing.

For now, it was only the outer perimeter, two squares deep. In other words, each class simply had to move away from the coast and shift slightly inward; avoiding large-scale combat would've been easy at that point.

But from the third day onward, that would almost certainly not be the case. The representatives of the Class C and Class D alliance, who set up a base in K13, began a discussion, joined by several students from both classes.

"Where've you been all morning? I even went to your tent to get ya, y'know?"

"My bad, I had some business to take care of."

When I offered a light apology with my right hand, Hashimoto stared at it quizzically.

"Ain't it kinda dirty?"

"It's nothing serious, don't worry about it. More importantly, let me hear what you were discussing."

"Hm? Oh, right—Kanzaki, please continue."

"I was just saying that we've reached a difficult phase. We've used most of our handheld provisions and it wouldn't be surprising if they were depleted by noon. Also, Sumida and Minamikata have seemed somewhat unwell since this morning. They themselves say they are still fine, but I don't believe they will last until the exam is over."

I received Kanzaki's report on the Class D students.

"If one is the VIP, it would be a bit of a hassle, but if they're guards, having them retire now may be an option. In any case, I want you to tell them not to overdo it. The damage will only be greater if they lie to themselves and force it."

"...Ah, yes. Saying that will likely put them both at ease. Moriyama, my apologies, but would you mind relaying Ayanokouji's words to them?"

Nodding as if to say, "Leave it to me," Moriyama headed off at a run toward the tents that were being taken down.

"But man, we're obviously runnin' low on supplies. We got nothin' but a bunch of starving folks over here, too."

Pressing his stomach lightly, Hashimoto muttered wearily.

"Yes. And it's already the third day of the exam; there must be a limit to how much longer we can continue collecting from a distance. Which means... a battle over supplies is finally about to begin. Let me hear your thoughts."

When Kanzaki asked me about our plan for the day, I nodded silently.

"There are broadly two methods for determining our plan. One is to envision the objective you wish to achieve and map out a path to it. The other is to gauge the enemy's aim and thwart their intentions."

I spread out the map and began to explain in a way that was easy for Hashimoto and Kanzaki to understand.

"On the first day, Class B—or rather, Ryuuen—launched a surprise attack on Class C. What do you suppose the reason was?"

"What's there to suppose? He figured he could deal a huge blow to the enemy by catching them off guard. It's the story of him taking a risk and successfully pulling it off, ain't it?"

"If the lottery results had been different and Class A was next to us, would he have attacked in the same way?"

Kanzaki crossed his arms, thought for a moment, then nodded.

"Wouldn't Class A have been the ideal enemy, instead? If you think about it that way, attacking becomes the obvious choice."

"My thinking is different. I believe that if Ryuuen couldn't launch a surprise attack on Class C, he wouldn't have initiated a fight using his trump card tactic from the very beginning. Why did it have to be the lower-ranked Class C? Because in order to win, he considers my existence to be one of the most troublesome obstacles."

"To Ryuuen, you're his arch-rival now. That makes you the best opponent to take down with a sneak attack."

"I can't say I don't get what you're saying, but even so, I can't accept the conclusion that he wouldn't have attacked Class A. Even if they weren't ideal, he should've had no problem attacking."

If they could knock the top-ranked Class A to last place, Class B would be able to pull itself much closer to that position. What Kanzaki wanted to say was simple.

"There's a troublesome presence in Class A from the start. Needless to say, it's Koenji. At the beginning, it was impossible to judge whether he intended to participate in this special exam or not. In fact, you felt he was an element of uncertainty too, didn't you?"

"...Yeah, that's true."

"Even if he didn't intend to participate, Koenji was still with Class A for a short time after the start. Launching a surprise attack there would create the unnecessary risk of waking a sleeping lion."

"I see... So if Koenji took issue with the surprise attack and cooperated with his class and by some chance launched a counterattack, the situation would instantly become impossible to read, is that it?"

Ichinose must have reported on that point as well. Kanzaki muttered.

"In fact, the Class B students who came into contact with Koenji were eliminated, after all... I see."

He was a person with enough potential to make one think he could change the course of the battle all by himself, a fact no one would deny.

"In any case, after much consideration, Ryuuen executed a surprise attack and gained a huge advantage over Class C. But now, compared to Class A, he's lost fourteen guards and can no longer use his core tactic of disabling the overall GPS. Now that the number of out-of-bounds areas is increasing, the value of this tactic is growing with each passing moment."

"If the opponent's GPS stops working when you start fighting, even for just thirty minutes, you won't know where they're coming from. It wouldn't be strange to be completely immobilized."

He himself demonstrated, through the surprise attack he launched, that a successful ambush could inflict enormous damage, even if only for a short time.

"So what's your take on it? Does Ryuuen plan to attack, or defend? Let me hear what you think."

"He'll wait until the last possible moment without launching a hasty attack. He's waiting for the time when the out-of-bounds areas expand, making it impossible to escape far away and forcing the four classes to gather whether they like it or not."

That was the closest thing to the optimal solution. The problem was whether Ryuuen could choose that answer. If he impatiently went after Class A or the allied classes, Class B might be eliminated surprisingly quickly.

"Then should we attack instead?"

"No, avoiding engagement is best for now. We'll stick to a defensive strategy, just like on the first and second days."

Even if we did nothing, the exam's end time was fixed.

A development in which we would all randomly fire at each other within the shrinking area was sure to come.

And that, in fact, was the very development we were hoping for.
